item.title: Venus transitting the Sun
item.description: The transit of Venus across the Sun in 2004. Taken by putting an Olympus Digital Camera up to the eyepiece of the Questar 3.5" with a continuum Solar filter.
item.media:description: The transit of Venus across the Sun in 2004. Taken by putting an Olympus Digital Camera up to the eyepiece of the Questar 3.5" with a continuum Solar filter.

item.title: Sun and Clouds GIF
item.description: 2011-11-08. Click this image to view a GIF movie of the active Sun and clouds passing by.
item.media:description: 2011-11-08. Click this image to view a GIF movie of the active Sun and clouds passing by.

item.title: The active Sun on Nov 8
item.description: The active Sun on Nov 8, 2011. Picture of the Sun projected on a white screen using a Celestron 6-inch telescope.
item.media:description: The active Sun on Nov 8, 2011. Picture of the Sun projected on a white screen using a Celestron 6-inch telescope.

item.title: The Sun Projected in the shade.
item.description: The Sun Projected in the shade. Nov 8, 2011. This picture shows how the 6-inch Celestron was used to project the Sun onto a white board under the shade of some black paper window drapes held up by rulers.
item.media:description: The Sun Projected in the shade. Nov 8, 2011. This picture shows how the 6-inch Celestron was used to project the Sun onto a white board under the shade of some black paper window drapes held up by rulers.

item.title: Projected Sun and clouds - 2012 Venus transit.
item.description: This is a projected image of the Sun during the transit of Venus (dark blob at the top) across the Sun in June 5 of 2012. The misty appearance is caused by passing clouds. The non-circular outline is caused by the light rays from the telescope reaching the screen at an oblique angle, as well as the view of the screen being oblique.
item.media:description: This is a projected image of the Sun during the transit of Venus (dark blob at the top) across the Sun in June 5 of 2012. The misty appearance is caused by passing clouds. The non-circular outline is caused by the light rays from the telescope reaching the screen at an oblique angle, as well as the view of the screen being oblique.

item.title: Transit of Venus across the Sun. June 5 2012.
item.description: Transit of Venus across the Sun. June 5 2012. The outline of Venus (and the Sun) is oblong because the light from the telescope was slightly oblique. Some minor sunspots are visible
item.media:description: Transit of Venus across the Sun. June 5 2012. The outline of Venus (and the Sun) is oblong because the light from the telescope was slightly oblique. Some minor sunspots are visible

item.title: Transit of Venus across the Sun. June 5 2012.
item.description: Transit of Venus across the Sun. June 5 2012. The grainy appearance is due to the screen. The darker sunspots are real. The transit lasted 6 hours.
item.media:description: Transit of Venus across the Sun. June 5 2012. The grainy appearance is due to the screen. The darker sunspots are real. The transit lasted 6 hours.

item.title: The Sun on July 16
item.description: The Sun on July 16, 2015. Projected on a screen using the Celestron 6-inch. This was during sunspot cycle 24, which had about half as many sunspots as the previous cycle. Some sunspots are visible but the Sun was dropping towards the 2020 minimum.
item.media:description: The Sun on July 16, 2015. Projected on a screen using the Celestron 6-inch. This was during sunspot cycle 24, which had about half as many sunspots as the previous cycle. Some sunspots are visible but the Sun was dropping towards the 2020 minimum.

item.title: Sunspot Video
item.description: 2016-01-29. Click to view an MP4 video of a sunspot moving across the field of view.
item.media:description: 2016-01-29. Click to view an MP4 video of a sunspot moving across the field of view.

item.title: The Sun through the H alpha telescope on 3/8/16.
item.description: The Sun through the H alpha (SolarMax II) telescope on 3/8/16. A bright prominence is visible at the bottom right. Dark filaments and brighter faculae are real features on the Sun, but some of the darker dots are not actually on the Sun. The misty appearance of the top right is not part of the Sun.
item.media:description: The Sun through the H alpha (SolarMax II) telescope on 3/8/16. A bright prominence is visible at the bottom right. Dark filaments and brighter faculae are real features on the Sun, but some of the darker dots are not actually on the Sun. The misty appearance of the top right is not part of the Sun.

item.title: Prominence on the Sun
item.description: Prominence on the Sun, Mar 8, 2016. Taken with the Canon T5i on the Coronado SolarMax II H-alpha telescope. These H-alpha telescope have a wavelength tuning filter which can give a wide variety of appearances. In this case, the main body of the Sun has little detail, but the prominences are visible along the bottom.
item.media:description: Prominence on the Sun, Mar 8, 2016. Taken with the Canon T5i on the Coronado SolarMax II H-alpha telescope. These H-alpha telescope have a wavelength tuning filter which can give a wide variety of appearances. In this case, the main body of the Sun has little detail, but the prominences are visible along the bottom.

item.title: Solar Disk Pan
item.description: 2017-06-02. Click to view this movie of several stills covering the entire solar disk.
item.media:description: 2017-06-02. Click to view this movie of several stills covering the entire solar disk.

item.title: The H-alpha Sun - 7/8/17
item.description: The H-alpha Sun - 7/8/17. The tunable narrow band filter on the SolarMax II is set to reveal some mottling on the Sun and a sunspot.
item.media:description: The H-alpha Sun - 7/8/17. The tunable narrow band filter on the SolarMax II is set to reveal some mottling on the Sun and a sunspot.

item.title: Prominances on the Sun - 7/8/17
item.description: The H-alpha Sun - 7/8/17. Here the tunable filter on the SolarMax II is set to reveal two major prominences on the Sun. Faculae (bright spots) are also visible, especially next to the sunspot.
item.media:description: The H-alpha Sun - 7/8/17. Here the tunable filter on the SolarMax II is set to reveal two major prominences on the Sun. Faculae (bright spots) are also visible, especially next to the sunspot.

item.title: Sunspot and prominences
item.description: Sunspot and prominences, 7/8/17. Canon T5i on the Coronado SolarMax II. A white-pink color is achieved in this exposure and etalon setting.
item.media:description: Sunspot and prominences, 7/8/17. Canon T5i on the Coronado SolarMax II. A white-pink color is achieved in this exposure and etalon setting.

item.title: Featureless Sun!? 5/14/19
item.description: Featureless Sun!? 5/14/19. Granted, this was near the sunspot minimum, but some settings of the Coronado SolarMax II do not show much detail even when it is present. This image was created by stacking multiple frames from a video - some alignment imperfections persist on the edges of the image.
item.media:description: Featureless Sun!? 5/14/19. Granted, this was near the sunspot minimum, but some settings of the Coronado SolarMax II do not show much detail even when it is present. This image was created by stacking multiple frames from a video - some alignment imperfections persist on the edges of the image.
